reviews.review_msg: The final project is a lot of work, but gives you an idea of what going into consulting will be like. She is well respected and knowledgeable in her field. The midterm was rough, but if you do the labs well they can saved your grade.

Quite possibly one of the best professors I've had at SFU. She is very clear in explanations, and very approachable even though she is incredibly smart. The term project was not as hard as everyone makes it out to be. Final was long but fun. Good thinking questions.

This term, she said she gave the highest mark on midterm EVER - 92%.  Something is wrong with that.  In 10 years of teaching you'd think one person could achieve an A+. Prepare for a ding on your GPA. Terrible notes, unnecessary additives, poorly organized! Simple, elegant material presented in an unnecessarily convoluted and confusing manner.

Content intensive course! Yes, she speeds through the lectures but it's necessary to get through all of the material; was available for help and asked before moving on if there were any questions. Text necessary, more examples in class would help;LOTS of work req'd but she knows her stuff and it's a useful course not a basket weaver like many here.
Final and midterm were really long; nobody left before the end in either. Labs are time-consuming and project took forever.

Her lectures are really fast, she doesn't explain concepts well or give many examples. She assumes that giving mathematical derivations for the equations is informative for students. Midterm was hard - class average 59%, final project took more than 40 hours to complete (3 week timeframe to do it in). Not very helpful in lab or in class.
Seems like a nice person but a devil lives inside of her

The course's structure presented many challenges: highly difficult midterm and final exams, with a class average of only 40% on the latter. Additionally, the scheduling of major assignments just before finals week added to the workload pressure. The pacing of the class hurts our grades, and making it difficult for students to adequately prepare.
